Posts.Content: Thank you, all! I didn't expect such thorough responses so soon! I appreciate each and every one of you answering me. Okay, so I'll relax a bit, LOL, especially when it comes to the scan. Thank you, Southsider, for pointing out that it is likely pointless. Also, I had not considered asking for a written copy of the pathology report. Will have my husband ask that we get one for our own records. And, yes, I do plan on being at all the appointments. My husband is very matter of fact and undramatic about this all—and also has a good sense of humor—so he had done ZERO research prior to the diagnosis. He was surprised at how much I'd done and at the questions I asked during our inital consult with the diagnosing docs. But that's how I operate. I keep panic at bay by learning all I can. I'm trying to strike a balance between being proactive, but not micromanaging this for him. It's hard, especially given that we're finding that almost every treatment has side effects that will certainly affect our relationship in one form or another. But, one step at a time. You all have helped me greatly. Thanks again and I'll let you know what we eventually decide.
Posts.Title: How Long to Wait?

Posts.Content: Hello Gentlemen, I hope it's okay that I post this query. My husband was diagnosed with PC two weeks ago, after an initial PSA test on a regular physical back at beginning of July came back as 4.5. Here is what the pathology report states: Right Prostate: adenocarcinoma, Geason score 3+4 (Grade Group 2, TC1), carcinoma involves multiple cores and approximately 10 percent of examined tissue Left Prostate: benign prostatic tissue 6 cores were taken from each side. He has not been scheduled for a bone scan or any other follow-up test, including genetic, as his urologist does not think it necessary (his words). This puzzles me, as I have since learned that scans and genetic tests are imperative. My husband is 54 years old. First PSA test was given two years ago. It was 2.5. Current numbers are: regular PSA 4.5, 4K score 28 percent, and free PSA is 8. Husband's current care team is comprised of a resident and a urological oncoloist with 25 years of experience performing radical prostatectomies. They are both at the University of New Mexico Cancer Center in Albuquerque. We met first with the resident, who believes that active surveillance is a definite possibility for my husband. Then the doctor came in, who advised "immediate" surgical treatment. By the time we finished talking, however, he very grudgingly said that "more than likely" this was not an immediate threat, and we could take a few months to get second opinions, etc. and then decide. The disconnect between these two recommendations is interesting, to say the least. In the meantime, my husband is seeking his second opinion at Integris, a cancer specialty clinic in OKC (where we live parttime), which takes a multidisciplinary team approach to treatment. Instead of shuttling the patient around from doctor to doctor, they meet with all specialists (surgeons and radiologists) at one time. They will likely do the PET scan, but we don't know yet. We expect to hear from Integris this week. Also considering sending slides to Dr. Epstein at John's Hopkins, but do not know what his lead time is. Will call this week. We also have a follow up PSA test scheduled for January 20th as part of our active surveillance approach until a second (or third) opinion suggests otherwise. My bottom line question is: how much time do we have to make a decision on treatment? Any thoughts you can share with me about time frames would be most appreciated. Thanks so much, CPG
Posts.Title: How Long to Wait?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Confirm the Gleason 4 with a second opinion. Epstein's lab at Hopkins is the state of the art. If G4 is confirmed you are a candidate for treatment. Your young age, G4, and volume are the critical factors. Because cancer wasn't hit on one side doesn't mean it's not there. Your young age is the most critical factor. G4 presenting so early implies an aggressive form of cancer, imo. At 54 it has a head start, and it will not go away or slow down. Silver lining, you caught it early making it very treatable. Early detection, early treatment is the mantra for aggressive forms of this disease. You have time to consider and educate yourself. Stay main stream and out of the weeds. Welcome to the club. G4, age, and volume do not make you a good candidate for AS, imo. Hi Another, Thanks for your thoughts. Quick question: what do you mean by "volume."

My husband was diagnosed with PC two weeks ago, after an initial PSA test on a regular physical back at beginning of July came back as 4.5. Here is what the pathology report states: Right Prostate: adenocarcinoma, Geason score 3+4 (Grade Group 2, TC1), carcinoma involves multiple cores and approximately 10 percent of examined tissue Left Prostate: benign prostatic tissue 6 cores were taken from each side. He has not been scheduled for a bone scan or any other follow-up test, including genetic, as his urologist does not think it necessary (his words). This puzzles me, as I have since learned that scans and genetic tests are imperative. My husband is 54 years old. First PSA test was given two years ago. It was 2.5. Current numbers are: regular PSA 4.5, 4K score 28 percent, and free PSA is 8. Husband's current care team is comprised of a resident and a urological oncoloist with 25 years of experience performing radical prostatectomies. They are both at the University of New Mexico Cancer Center in Albuquerque. We met first with the resident, who believes that active surveillance is a definite possibility for my husband. By the time we finished talking, however, he very grudgingly said that "more than likely" this was not an immediate threat, and we could take a few months to get second opinions, etc. and then decide. The disconnect between these two recommendations is interesting, to say the least. In the meantime, my husband is seeking his second opinion at Integris, a cancer specialty clinic in OKC (where we live parttime), which takes a multidisciplinary team approach to treatment. We expect to hear from Integris this week. Also considering sending slides to Dr. Epstein at John's Hopkins, but do not know what his lead time is. Will call this week. We also have a follow up PSA test scheduled for January 20th as part of our active surveillance approach until a second (or third) opinion suggests otherwise. My bottom line question is: how much time do we have to make a decision on treatment? Any thoughts you can share with me about time frames would be most appreciated. Thanks so much, CPG

Current numbers are: regular PSA 4.5, 4K score 28 percent, and free PSA is 8. Husband's current care team is comprised of a resident and a urological oncoloist with 25 years of experience performing radical prostatectomies. They are both at the University of New Mexico Cancer Center in Albuquerque. We met first with the resident, who believes that active surveillance is a definite possibility for my husband. Then the doctor came in, who advised "immediate" surgical treatment. By the time we finished talking, however, he very grudgingly said that "more than likely" this was not an immediate threat, and we could take a few months to get second opinions, etc. and then decide. The disconnect between these two recommendations is interesting, to say the least. In the meantime, my husband is seeking his second opinion at Integris, a cancer specialty clinic in OKC (where we live parttime), which takes a multidisciplinary team approach to treatment. Instead of shuttling the patient around from doctor to doctor, they meet with all specialists (surgeons and radiologists) at one time. They will likely do the PET scan, but we don't know yet. We expect to hear from Integris this week. Also considering sending slides to Dr. Epstein at John's Hopkins, but do not know what his lead time is. Will call this week. We also have a follow up PSA test scheduled for January 20th as part of our active surveillance approach until a second (or third) opinion suggests otherwise. My bottom line question is: how much time do we have to make a decision on treatment? Any thoughts you can share with me about time frames would be most appreciated. Thanks so much, CPG
Posts.Title: How Long to Wait?

Posts.Content: Hello Gentlemen, I hope it's okay that I post this query. My husband was diagnosed with PC two weeks ago, after an initial PSA test on a regular physical back at beginning of July came back as 4.5. Here is what the pathology report states: Right Prostate: adenocarcinoma, Geason score 3+4 (Grade Group 2, TC1), carcinoma involves multiple cores and approximately 10 percent of examined tissue Left Prostate: benign prostatic tissue 6 cores were taken from each side. He has not been scheduled for a bone scan or any other follow-up test, including genetic, as his urologist does not think it necessary (his words). This puzzles me, as I have since learned that scans and genetic tests are imperative. My husband is 54 years old. First PSA test was given two years ago. It was 2.5. Current numbers are: regular PSA 4.5, 4K score 28 percent, and free PSA is 8. Husband's current care team is comprised of a resident and a urological oncoloist with 25 years of experience performing radical prostatectomies. They are both at the University of New Mexico Cancer Center in Albuquerque. We met first with the resident, who believes that active surveillance is a definite possibility for my husband. Then the doctor came in, who advised "immediate" surgical treatment. By the time we finished talking, however, he very grudgingly said that "more than likely" this was not an immediate threat, and we could take a few months to get second opinions, etc. and then decide. The disconnect between these two recommendations is interesting, to say the least. In the meantime, my husband is seeking his second opinion at Integris, a cancer specialty clinic in OKC (where we live parttime), which takes a multidisciplinary team approach to treatment. Instead of shuttling the patient around from doctor to doctor, they meet with all specialists (surgeons and radiologists) at one time. They will likely do the PET scan, but we don't know yet. We expect to hear from Integris this week. Also considering sending slides to Dr. Epstein at John's Hopkins, but do not know what his lead time is. Will call this week. We also have a follow up PSA test scheduled for January 20th as part of our active surveillance approach until a second (or third) opinion suggests otherwise. My bottom line question is: how much time do we have to make a decision on treatment? Any thoughts you can share with me about time frames would be most appreciated. Thanks so much, CPG

Posts.Title: How Long to Wait?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another Confirm the Gleason 4 with a second opinion. Epstein's lab at Hopkins is the state of the art. If G4 is confirmed you are a candidate for treatment. Your young age, G4, and volume are the critical factors. Because cancer wasn't hit on one side doesn't mean it's not there. Your young age is the most critical factor. G4 presenting so early implies an aggressive form of cancer, imo. At 54 it has a head start, and it will not go away or slow down. Silver lining, you caught it early making it very treatable. Early detection, early treatment is the mantra for aggressive forms of this disease. You have time to consider and educate yourself. Stay main stream and out of the weeds. Welcome to the club. G4, age, and volume do not make you a good candidate for AS, imo. Hi Another, Thanks for your thoughts. Quick question: what do you mean by "volume."
Posts.Title: How Long to Wait?
